Kahaani was released worldwide on 9 March 2012.
Critics praised the screenplay, the cinematography and the performances of the lead actors of Kahaani.
Kahaani was released worldwide on March 9, 2012.
Following critical acclaim and word-of-mouth publicity, the film earned ₹1.04 billion (US$12 million) worldwide in 50 days.
The film won several awards, including three National Film Awards and five Filmfare Awards.

Vidya Bagchi, a character in the movie Kahaani, arrives in Kolkata from London during the Durga Puja festivities in search of her missing husband Arnab Bagchi.
Vidya claims that Arnab went to Kolkata on an assignment for the National Data Center (NDC).
assassin working undercover as a life insurance agent kills Agnes D'Mello at the entrance of her house before she provides further help regarding former employee Milan Damji's file.
attempts to obtain Milan Damji's records attract the attention of Bhaskaran K. And Khan, two Intelligence Bureau officials in Delhi.

former IB agent Milan Damji was responsible for the poison gas attack, revealed by Intelligence Bureau deputy Khan.

Bengali film actor Prosenjit Chatterjee encouraged Ghosh to shoot in Kolkata. Ghosh selected Kolkata for several reasons: the director's acquaintance with the city, its mix of modernity and old-world charm, and budget constraints as Kolkata is a cheaper location than Mumbai or Delhi where most Bollywood films are shot.

After his two preceding directorial ventures—Aladin and Home Delivery (2005)—performed poorly at the box office, Ghosh admitted in an interview that Kahaani was his last chance to create a niche as a director.

Ghosh finally selected Kolkata for several reasons: the director's acquaintance with the city, its mix of modernity and old-world charm, and budget constraints as most Bollywood films are shot in Mumbai or Delhi where Kolkata is a cheaper location than.

Ghosh went against the expectations of casting a popular actor from Bollywood. He signed Bengali actor Abir Chatterjee to play Vidya's husband. According to Ghosh, popular Bollywood actors were not willing to work with him after his two previous flops.
Before the shooting of the film began, Vidya started to use a prosthetic belly to look as close to authentically pregnant as possible.

Bob Biswas's polite demeanor is often referred to as Binito Bob by Ghosh during character briefing for actor Saswata Chatterjee. This phrase highlights the contrast between Bob's cold-blooded killer persona and his courteous behavior.
Bob Biswas's polite mannerisms are a significant part of his character, as emphasized by director Ghosh during the briefing for actor Saswata Chatterjee.
In their discussions, director Ghosh and actor Saswata Chatterjee included the character trait of a paunch in Bob Biswas's portrayal.
Director Ghosh and actor Saswata Chatterjee also included the character trait of a bald patch in Bob Biswas's portrayal during their discussions.
Actor Saswata Chatterjee devised the mannerism of rubbing his nails together as some Indians believe doing that helps prevent hair loss, which was well-noted and praised by the viewers.
Director Ghosh expressed surprise at how Bob Biswas was received as a cult figure by fans, highlighting the convincing portrayal of Bob's ordinariness by actor Saswata Chatterjee.
Chatterjee stated in an interview that he did not identify with the Rana character due to the difference between his urban upbringing and Rana's rural background.
To prepare for his role, Chatterjee visited police stations and did some research on their work, mindset, and other relevant things.
The character Khan was envisaged as a ruthless, arrogant, expletive-spewing officer who cares nothing about the emotional or social consequences of his behavior.
Siddiqui was surprised on being offered the role and wondered how he could portray the arrogance needed for the character.

Ghosh built Khan as a character with lean physical build but full of mental strength, loyalty, and patriotism. Khan smokes a relatively cheap brand of cigarette (Gold Flake) despite his high official post.
Ghosh's use of guerrilla filmmaking to avoid unwanted attention in the streets of Kolkata during filming.
The climax was shot on the night of Vijayadashami in the premises of a Barowari (publicly organised) Durga Puja celebration in the Ballygunge neighbourhood of Kolkata.
Shot mostly without artificial light to avoid unwanted attention during filming in Kolkata, as he had assisted others to shoot documentaries in Kolkata using the art of guerrilla filmmaking.

Filming took place on the streets of Kolkata, where Ghosh often employed the art of guerrilla filmmaking (shooting in real locations without any previous knowledge given to onlookers) to avoid unwanted attention.

Most of the crowd in the climax were not actors, and their job was to appreciate the camera angles and accordingly apply sindoor (vermilion) on Vidya's face so that accidental exposure of her eyes to sindoor could be avoided.
The climax was shot on the night of Vijayadashami in the premises of a Barowari (publicly organised) Durga Puja celebration in the Ballygunge neighbourhood of Kolkata.
Shooting locations in Kolkata included Kalighat Metro station, Nonapukur tram depot, old houses of North Kolkata and others.
The film was shot in 64 days during which the Durga Puja festival of 2010 took place.

Kahaani is a woman's film that explores feminist themes and role reversals, breaking stereotypes, turning clichés inside out, and depicts the journey of a strong female character in a male-dominated society.
For director Sujoy Ghosh, Kahaani is not only a thriller but also a study of motherhood. The instinct of a mother to protect her baby inspired him to develop the story.

The fleeting hint of romance between Rana and Vidya in the film is a delicate one, which Ghosh describes as 'the most progressive thing'. This romance suggests that a man can fall in love with a pregnant woman. The director explains that initially Rana was fascinated by Vidya's computer skills, as she is literally a hero in his eyes. As the story unfolds, Rana moves from being fascinated to trying to protect her.

A major protagonist of the film is Kolkata itself and the director pays a fond yet understated tribute to the city by incorporating imagery such as yellow taxis, leisurely trams, congested traffic, claustrophobic metros, dilapidated brick houses, tapering alleys, rajnigandhas, lal paad saris, and piping hot luchis. The reviewer notes that the protagonist city does not depend on the tropes of Kolkata culture typically used in Bollywood films.
According to Bengali director Srijit Mukherji, the portrayal of Kolkata in Kahaani was akin to Lonely Planet exotica on the city.
Durga Puja is a prominent festival that falls in autumn.
In the story, the allegorical yearly return of goddess Durga to slay the demon Mahishasura is alluded to.
The festivities of Durga Puja include idols, immersion processions, and pandals.

node_2: entire crowd of women draped in white saris with red borders
edge: According to Uddalak Mukherjee, 'Durga Puja, with its paraphernalia of idols, immersion processions, pandals, even an entire crowd of women draped in white saris with red borders, is central to the film's visual aesthetic.'
The festivities of Durga Puja are a part of the celebration of this festival.
According to a review in Rediff.com, 'the festivities of Durga Puja are well known for their celebration in Kolkata.'
The review also praised the depiction of the festivities in Kolkata.
acknowledges the allusions to Ray's films

In one scene, Vidya asks the manager of the guest house why there is no hot water although the signboard had claimed 'running hot water'. The manager explains that the sign refers for his errand boy, who runs to deliver hot water in a kettle whenever required. This alludes to a similar scene in Ray's Joi Baba Felunath (1979).

The way Vidya looks out and moves from window to window in the guest-house room is reminiscent of Ray's Charulata (1964), where the actress Madhabi Mukherjee enjoys glimpses of the outside world through the blinds of windows.
He also acknowledges the influence of Mahanagar (1963), another Ray film noted for its portrayal of Kolkata.
Ghosh expresses his inspiration from Ray's Nayak (1966) to plan the portrayal of complex emotional issues between Vidya and the police officer Rana, especially Rana's awe in the presence of Vidya.
Ghosh shot a similar scene, hoping the audience would become 'like Vidya's fellow passenger.'
Both films have a similar fake-pregnancy twist in their plots, as critically noted.
Critics have compared the sequences towards the end that explain the missing pieces of the mystery in Kahaani with the explanatory sequences in The Usual Suspects.

Ghosh admitted being inspired by visually striking films of the 1970s and 1980s, including Deewaar.

The 58th Filmfare Awards nominated the film Kahaani for six of their categories.
At the 19th Colors Screen Awards, Kahaani received thirteen nominations and Vidya won the Best Actress award.
At the 19th Colors Screen Awards, Kahaani received thirteen nominations and Ghosh won the Best Director award.
At the 14th Zee Cine Awards, Kahaani won five awards including Best Film (Critics).
At the 19th Colors Screen Awards, Kahaani received thirteen nominations and won the Best Story award.
Kahaani was nominated for and won the Best Actress award at various awards ceremonies, including the 19th Colors Screen Awards, the 14th Zee Cine Awards, and the Stardust Awards.
At the 60th National Film Awards, Namrata Rao won the Best Editing award for her work on Kahaani.
At the 60th National Film Awards, Nawazuddin Siddiqui won a Special Jury award for his work on Kahaani.
In 2014, a Telugu remake of Kahaani titled Anaamika was released, directed by Sekhar Kammula and featuring Nayantara as the lead character.
In 2014, a Tamil version of Kahaani titled Nee Enge En Anbe was released, directed by Sekhar Kammula and featuring Nayantara as the lead character.
An English-language remake of Kahaani, entitled Deity, will be directed by Niels Arden Oplev and produced by Yashraj Films.

Following Kahaani's success, Kolkata became a preferred destination for Bollywood filmmakers as they felt the landscapes of Mumbai and Delhi were overused for several decades, while Kolkata retained its unique visuals such as metro trains, rickety trams, hand-pulled rickshaws, dingy bylanes, palatial mansions, dilapidated houses of North Kolkata, roadside eateries, ghats of river Ganga, British-era buildings, restaurants and iconic structures and areas including Howrah Bridge, Kalighat Temple, Nakhoda Mosque, Kumortuli idol-making district and Victoria Memorial.
The lodge which hosted Vidya Bagchi in the film, became a local attraction after the release of Kahaani.
The potbellied contract killer Bob Biswas became an Internet phenomenon, after Kahaani's success. The monologue he repeatedly uses just before murdering his victims was used in different memes.
